content: Gay Adoption Win in Florida The National Center for Lesbian Rights scored a decisive win for gay parents in Florida, when an appeals court unanimously agreed on Wednesday that the Sunshine State must honor second-parent adoptions by same-sex couples granted in other states. The Florida court of appeals reversed a lower court ruling and held that Florida must give full faith and credit to adoptions granted to same-sex couples by other states. About half of U.S. states allow second-parent adoptions by same-sex couples, according to Shannon Price Minter, legal director for NCLR. Full article at >>> >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid83947.asp

content: I've always wondered why Senior Citizens go to Florida when they retire. It's hot and humid which promotes rapid growth of mold and weeds. Your constantly bending over pulling weeds out of your flower beds (Chiropractor's delight) and fighting the unrelenting mold that grows on the sides of your home and on your sidewalks & driveways (very slippery). The flying bugs and Fire Ants rule supreme and we have cock roaches that are the size of locust, we call them Palmetto bugs but they're just giant roaches. I have to go on Fire Ant Patrol around the yard every three days using expensive ant killer chemicals to keep them from overrunning the property and I still get bit because the sneaky little critters are hiding in the flower beds and bite me when I bend over and reach down to pull out the weeds that popped up overnight!! Back on topic; There are some angry seething folks down here that are as mad as a swarm of Africanized bees over this Appeal Court ruling. The plot thickens

content: ... and then you have this little jewel pop-up. Louisiana Moves to Limit Gay Adoptions The Louisiana house voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to pass a bill that would prohibit the issuance of birth certificates that list the names of two unmarried parents who adopt a Louisiana-born child in another state. The legislation, which passed by a vote of 77-18, stems from a December ruling in which U.S. district judge Jay Zainey sided with two California men seeking a joint birth certificate for the Shreveport-born child they adopted in New York in 2006. The state is appealing the ruling, according to the Times-Picayune . More at ... >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid84288.asp
